subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove and today my topic is “Playing With Magick”.
I have to tell you that when I was much, much younger, and
frankly a bit more foolish than I am now at the age of 71, I had a big
interest in ritual magic. In fact, to be honest, in the environment that I was in, having moved to Berkeley in
1969, magic was in the air. People were thinking about magic, talking about magic, and, indeed,
while I was working on my doctoral degree in
parapsychology at Berkeley, a young man named Isaac Bonewits
did an interdisciplinary
undergraduate degree in magic and he actually wrote a book at the time called Real Magic.
Interestingly, we had one of the same professors. I knew Isaac at the time –
he was well-known on the Berkeley campus – and there were many people at the time
who considered themselves occultists and they were friends of mine.
When I did my very first radio program on
KPFA FM in Berkeley, it was about these people, the local occult
community, Isaac Bonewits being one of the central figures.
But, there were the New Reformed Druids of North America, there were people who belonged to
what was called the O.T.O., the Ordo Templi Orientis,
which was an organization founded by Aleister Crowley. Aleister Crowley’s
“auto-hagiography,” as he called it, was pretty much essential reading.
But now, as I look back on it, I think of Crowley as a tragic figure.
He ended his life as a heroin addict in
1947. People reveled in his early writings. He seemed to have such
potential as a poet, as a
literary figure. A friend of people like William Butler Yeats,
the Nobel laureate poet who was also a member of the Order of the Golden Dawn
in England - an order of people who studied
magical grimoires, who
created tarot cards and who
practiced various forms of ritual magic, particularly a complex form that involved
deep study of the Hebrew Kabbalah.
So, this was the milieu at the time and one of the books that really caught my fancy
back then was known as The Sacred Magic of Abramelin the Mage. It was a
magical ritual in which
you had to live in total isolation,
in total solitude for six months. After six months of
solitude and prayer you could invoke your holy
guardian angel. And
with the help of your holy guardian angel you could perform any
kind of magic. I mean, you could raise armies, you could
have vast wealth, things of this sort. I
understand that that book actually had quite an influence on Crowley himself.
Well, it was in this milieu that I
began to engage
in, perhaps thinking that I had potential as a
magician – in fact I guess I had a certain intuition for it, a certain knack for it –
I began really to develop an intimate relationship with these people and
at the same time I was a graduate student, still in my criminology years.
I wrote a grant for an organization called the Health Information Program on the Berkeley campus.
The idea was, because drug use was a problem on the Berkeley campus,
I thought that the best way to address drug use was to provide
alternative ways to get high without using drugs. So, this was the Health Information Program.
It was funded by the Chancellor. The Chancellor provided a house for us. I moved into the house and
we had what was called a tribal council. There were faculty
sponsors and a couple other people. A married couple – who were not students on the Berkeley campus
but were friends of one of the professors who had sponsored the project – were also invited to move into this house
with me. I was the director of the program. We sponsored classes in
organic cooking, we had classes in yoga and meditation, we brought in various parapsychologists to
talk about their research. So, we had an active program and we were reaching out to the student community.
But, I discovered that the married couple living with me were cheating.
It was trivial, it was really petty, but I made a big issue of it because they were using the
Health Information Program telephone for their personal phone calls and they had run up a phone bill of
$40 or so. They denied it, they claimed that they hadn’t made these phone calls
and I knew perfectly well that they had, and I made an issue and the tribal council had to meet and decide, and
everybody could tell they were lying,
but the question was: “Is this the issue we wanted to have?” I was full of
righteous indignation and what I did is,
how some people working with ritual magic – which is very old, it goes back to all ancient cultures,
it’s found today in pretty much every religion as well – they call it theurgy,
higher magic. But I decided I was going to invoke
magical principles to address this injustice. I had the tarot card for
“Justice” pinned up to the wall above my
bed in the bedroom where I was sleeping, and next to it I had my hunting knife
strapped up, the knife of justice, the sword of justice.
But see, the thing is, when you work with
magic – as my friend Gary Zukav, author of The Seat of the Soul, once explained to me – the result you’re going to
get is based on your own karma. Well, I was young and naive,
I hadn’t really any clue as to what my karma might be in this situation.
I should say something else because my
parapsychological colleague and friend, Dean Radin, has just written a book about magic and
parapsychology, and he points out that the fundamental principles behind magic are really the same principles that
parapsychologists study:
extrasensory perception,
psychokinesis, and also the Jungian principles of synchronicity. In any case, there I was,
engaged in this conflict with these dishonest people,
invoking justice in a magical context,
using the tarot card image of Justice
which has the sword of justice, and my own little hunting knife strapped
on the wall - maybe above, or beneath,
I forget which - the tarot card, that was a way of focusing my consciousness on,
one might say,
manipulating the gods of synchronicity to address this problem. And addressed it got, because
one night, at like 2:00 in the morning, I
was in bed, and this couple burst into my bedroom and
threw a knife at me. They said, “We are about to kill you. Pick up this knife and fight.” Now, I
didn’t want to pick up the knife, I had no interest in violence.
I’ve always been, thankfully, a non-violent person – in fact, a conscientious objector –
but what I did do was stand up. I got out of bed. I
was stark naked.
They also had prepared a pot of boiling water and they threw it on me
and I suffered some minor
scalding. But the intriguing thing was, at that moment
I felt possessed, as if I were Jesus Christ, to be quite honest.
I had no fear, I
was calm – as I mentioned,
I was naked – I just walked towards them and I must have really
frightened them, because they scattered as quickly as they could. I went to the clinic to be treated for the
scalding. They had a clinic in Berkeley open all night -
it was called The Free Clinic, and my friends, some of my magical friends, worked there actually as volunteers -
and
I called some of the faculty members
from the program, who said, “Why are you always rubbing our noses in the truth?”
That was from the professor who had sponsored this couple. Anyway,
the tribal council met – I was
still being
treated, they met without me – and they decided the best way to address this situation is
to get rid of all of the parties to the conflict. I was asked to leave, the other couple was asked to leave.
The lady involved was actually
convicted of assault.
The members, the faculty of the tribal council certainly wanted to
protect the reputation of the university, and they asked me not to press charges. I agreed not to, but when the DA
saw the report, because a report had been filed –
as I recall my girlfriend filed the report at the time –
but the DA was aware that this particular couple had been engaged in other similar incidents.
So, the DA pressed charges, there was a trial, I
testified and there was a conviction.
I went on with my life. I went on to create a doctoral degree in
parapsychology, and move on, but the lesson for me
from all of that was “not to play with magic.” It was a harrowing experience
really. It was one I didn’t particularly want to repeat. I remember
calling my father up and telling him this horrible assault had occurred on me in the middle of the night.
My dear father, who of course I love, said, “Well, what did you do to provoke it?”
I had to explain to him, “I need your support right now; I don’t need you
asking me how I provoked it,” because I considered myself innocent. But in retrospect,
no, I wasn’t exactly innocent.
I had invoked the sword of justice, and the sword of justice can cut in both directions.
So, it was my lesson about not playing with magic if you don’t
really, really know what you’re doing. And frankly, do any of us really, really know what we’re doing in that realm?
I kind of think not.
But as I mentioned earlier, there are higher forms of magic – theurgy –
we’ve talked about anthroposophy and their concept of initiation into the higher realms
of spiritual reality. That’s really what
occurs in most religions. It’s, I think, the idea behind the Catholic Mass,
which one could call a magical ritual. So,
it’s probably one of the reasons why many religions believe that if you practice
magic under the auspices of
their religion, of their priesthood, of their hierarchy,
then it’s okay, but it’s not okay if you try and do it on your own. Well,
I can tell you this: many of my old Berkeley
occultist friends would disagree with that and would disagree with it heartily.
It’s not as if I don’t have enormous love
for occultists – I do –
in fact, for anybody engaged in intuition and psychic work.
I really do, my heart is so open for people who do that work. But I have to say, I’m not aware of
people who practice magic like that
having any great successes. I’m aware of many small successes and
I do think it’s very
important, as I’ve mentioned
many times, I think in these segments, to maintain a healthy mental attitude
and to work on cultivating
your own mind and your own thoughts in the most positive way of all. I suppose even the use of
affirmations, such as “I love myself unconditionally,
and I really love the way that I love myself unconditionally.”
That’s, you could say, a form of magic as well, in the healthiest of ways.
So, I’ll leave you with this thought:
how has magic, if at all, how has magic played a role in your life?
Thank you for being with me.
